threads.com:
Stargaze is a /co/ collaborative space where anons pitch concepts, write episodes, and draw production art for the greatest toy commercial animated series that never was (but everyone still remembers) : Stargaze and the Sentinels of Starlight!

>The story thus far
Star-ro, Prince of the cracked planet Astray, wields the Royal Blaster (a relic of immeasurable power containing the last shard of the Lightstar) against the forces of evil as the Hero Stargaze!

Alongside him in this noble fight against the fearsome creature of the void Nebillious and all agents of evil in the galaxy are a wide cast of friends and comrades, the Sentinels of Starlight.
Chief among them
>Conshock
the cloven hoofed psychic pugilist
>Usra-La
The beautiful yet hot tempered Bar-Barean shaman warrior
>Rock-it
the fearsome yet kind hearted veteran of the Geosphere
>Lanstar
The cocksure and tech savvy friend of Star-ro
>Comet
The half Baastanian half sister of Star-ro, always causing mischief

Along with the cerebral Trancia, illustrious Pum-mel, fearsome Krogdar, shifty Shang-Xu, packrat scrapper Tonns, warrior of the shadows Jet-Hawk, honorable Hammer Hex, the incredible Robo-Puppy, and many more!

Fighting the villainous legions of the Astrayan traitor Warmaster, the voracious Hogmaw, the rogue robotic AI Wireshark, the seductive insect queen Cicadre and her manipulative assassin Scorpionic, the metal-eating Jaw-breaker, the mysterious and vicious technomancer Sigil, and the master of evil himself: The Nefarious Nebullious!
Creature of terror, the void made form with the dastardly ability to SUMMON SEVERAL HUNDRED SMOKE SNAKES! Enemy of all who wish for peace in the lightstar galaxy. He seeks the Royal Blaster and should he get it cosmos will never be the same!

Last thread: https://desuarchive.org/co/thread/134049654/#134049654
Do your part in this fight against the evil of declining toy sales!
See you....OUT THERE!

Nearly all of the Futurama cast has this certain level of aloof-ness that makes them loveable. It's a certain amount of innocence that you can't help but smile at. Zoidberg has the most of this, and he's the butt of a lot of jokes, so it gives him a huge amount of charm. Even Bender, for all his many flaws (contrary to his belief) is just a few years old, and his childish behavior is part of what makes his shitty behavior amusing instead of infuriating.

If I were to pick who is the least likeable character I'd pick Hermes. He really doesn't do very much, he's very plain compared to the others, and isn't the driving force in quite as many jokes.
Plus, due to that busybody nature of his, he lacks said aloofness.

threads.sub: Changing the world for the better
threads.com:
There's a schizo on /co/ whose been talking about how bad Capeshit is. Not gonna like the thread, it's STILL going on as we speak, find it yourself.

However, there IS one point that he brings up that fascinates me: Superheroes don't really make any progress in their stories and don't make the world a better place. I remember the comic Superman: Peace on Earth where he tried to end world hunger and it did not work for various reasons. And then I remember the Justice Lords episode of Justice League where the world is now at peace but it's very clear it's not a happy place.

Considering most superheroes work outside the law, even IF superheroes worked for the government, followed the laws, made everyone KNOW they're not a god and NOT above the law, and that they genuinely want to make the world a better place...could they, though?

All told, I genuinely WANT to write a superhero story...but how could a superhero REALLY make the world a better place without being the end all, BE all? How could a superhero REALLY end crime, corruption, war, world hunger, terrorism, and such, without looking like friggin' Homelander?

>Season 2 is right behind it and hits story beats really well
>Season 3's first half is on-par with seasons 1 and 2 and then nosedives in the second half
>Outside of a few standout episodes, season 4 is garbage
>Season 5 feels a little better but the ending is CLEARLY rushed after CN didn't order a new season
>The movie is maybe the best thing to come out of the franchise, if not then it's at least the best it's been since that first half of season 3
>Future is a mixed bag with some really solid elements and some that just fall flat

honestly hard disagree on s1 and the movie being the best - s1 has really slow pacing and the most filler, and it's not until the second half that they actually start to figure out what the gems really are and start to dive into what turns into the show's greatest strengths. the movie has absolutely banger musical numbers, but also way too many (like 11 in an hour-and-a-half movie lmao), and there are tons of impossible-to-ignore plotholes that drag it down pretty hard, including creating a retroactive plothole in change your mind (if rejuvenation is the closest you can get to erasing a gem without shattering it, and rejuvenated gems don't cycle through previous forms, why is white convinced that pink is gone when steven's gem cycles through both of her previous forms?). s2 is easily the best in terms of plot progression and characterization imo

future is also kind of a dumpster fire with a small handful of standout scenes that are almost entirely carried by zach's performance as steven, and the ending is completely worthless

Pic related has reconciled me with Milo Manara.
Previously, I only saw him as an unimaginative, if technically gifted, artist with a bad case of sameface and fishface.

However, in this series: Scenario is solid, so is rythm, composition is glorious, inclusion of Renaissance paintings as backgrounds is top-notch, and faces and expressions are way more varied and dynamic than usual.

It also helps that I read an interview of the guy where he explains how he sees his characters as actors playing roles. What seems like sameface is, in his mind, no different from a director employing a particular actor on all his movies. And indeed, Manara can produce more than one woman when he needs to.

I still don't get the hype behind the Déclic, tho.

>>134376356
A very abrupt ending to an awfully written sequel to a beloved show. After an episode long final battle between Primal and Megatron ending in both being absorbed by Cybertron itself, the planet and all Transformers are reformatted to be techno-organic beingd in an attempt to hammer an awfully contrived message about balance between nature and technology. Should be a big moment, but the show fucks up even that - in less than 2 minutes they end multiple subplots (most with no more than 2 lines of dialogue) and say farewell to Optimus (in about 20 words). Then the show just ends without actually showing anything specific about this brave new world.
It's an interesting idea, dreadful execution kind of deal - much like the whole show.
